p: Human granulocytic anaplasmosis (HGA) is another emerging tick-borne zoonosis, which was first reported in the United States in 1990 and in Europe in 1997 [ 45]. As the causative rickettsia was reclassified from the genus Ehrlichia to Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the disease name was changed from human granulocytic ehrlichiosis to HGA in 2001 [ 22, 45]. The pathogen causes the disease by infecting human neutrophils [ 21, 46]. The symptoms of HGA are similar to HME, and deaths from HGA are approximately 0.6% of those infected and typically involve those immunocompromised individuals, usually 10 or more days after disease onset [ 43, 46].
